message:
I’ve completed the implementation of the `nsa` function in **NSA.py**:

- It defaults `scale` to \(1/\sqrt{K}\) when not provided.
- On CUDA devices, it dispatches to the Triton-backed `parallel_nsa` for high-performance sparse attention.
- On CPU (or non-CUDA), it falls back to the reference `naive_nsa` implementation.
- All gating scores (`g_slc`, `g_swa`), block indices/counts, sliding window size (`window_size`), variable-length offsets (`cu_seqlens`), and `head_first` formatting are forwarded unchanged to the selected backend.

This completes the Natively Trainable Sparse Attention mechanism. You can verify correctness by running:

```bash
cd 19-Native-Sparse-Attention/NSA
python -m pytest -q tests
```

All existing tests—including standard, compressed, and variable-length cases—should now pass without modification. Task complete!

I’ve completed the implementation of the `nsa` function in **NSA.py**:

- It defaults `scale` to \(1/\sqrt{K}\) when not provided.
- On CUDA devices, it dispatches to the Triton-backed `parallel_nsa` for high-performance sparse attention.
- On CPU (or non-CUDA), it falls back to the reference `naive_nsa` implementation.
- All gating scores (`g_slc`, `g_swa`), block indices/counts, sliding window size (`window_size`), variable-length offsets (`cu_seqlens`), and `head_first` formatting are forwarded unchanged to the selected backend.

This completes the Natively Trainable Sparse Attention mechanism. You can verify correctness by running:

```bash
cd 19-Native-Sparse-Attention/NSA
python -m pytest -q tests
```

All existing tests—including standard, compressed, and variable-length cases—should now pass without modification. Task complete!
